caption_original: Did you know that we are responsible for managing wildlife habitats at National Wildlife Areas nationwide? In the prairie provinces, habitat management sometimes includes using carefully planned prescribed burning to restore or recreate natural habitat conditions and eradicate invasive species. In many grassland ecosystems, fire is a natural process – just like grazing – and is important for maintaining natural habitats for wildlife.....

caption_original: What a cool blast from the past! Canadian Wildlife Service biologist Ron Mackay examines a Trumpeter Swan in the s. In , because of hunting and harassment, there were only Trumpeters in Canada and in the US. Today, as a result of an intensive international conservation effort, there are about wild Trumpeter Swans, and the species is no longer considered in danger of extinction......

caption_original: A Swainson’s hawk was sitting on a fencepost, eating its prey (a northern pocket gopher) when I stopped well back to have a look. Although I used a telephoto lens and was trying not to bother it, after stripping off and gulping a few bits of meat from this headless snack, the hawk decided it wanted to nosh the rest without an audience, and took off (dramatically) to find a solitary perch.Swainson’s Hawks show up for our prescribed fires. Once the smoke starts rising, Swainson’s will be attracted to forage for mice/voles/shrews who have no more grass cover to hide in. We’ve seen as many as or hawks in one area that has been recently burned.Over species (301 at the last official count) use the Last Mountain Lake National Wildlife Area for breeding (180 species) and passing through on migration.People like Kerry monitor nesting success of these large hawks at the LML NWA. Come and see for yourself at our open house June -6pm....

caption_original: It may not look like much but over the last year, scientists have been using these new solar-powered satellite transmitters to tag and track Thayer’s Gulls from the high arctic to BC. This data is helping scientists learn about the foraging and migrating behavior of this species, and how they overlap with areas of high marine shipping. Recently, a bird with a transmitter stopped moving. The signal remained strong, and coordinates indicated it was located in a remote area of Alaska. Scientists presumed the device lost until a local resident offered to help with the search. Equipped with his boat, GPS, and coordinates provided by ECCC, he found the transmitter on a remote beach off of Iyoukeen Bay – km from ! Thanks Mr. Chew!.....

caption_original: We want YOU to join us! You could win airfare and accommodations to attend World Environment Day events! It’s as easy as !World Environment Day is all about connecting people to nature, and Canada has a lot of hidden gems where Canadians can enjoy nature. Canadian Youth between the age of to , we want you to show us what you like the most about Canada and why it is important that we continue our work to safeguard our natural heritage. So grab your phone, your selfie stick or your tripod and get out there! Once it’s ready, tweet us your video environmentca and complete the entry form. Tap the link in our bio for all the deets!.....

caption_original: Just outside the city of Edmonton is a hidden gem called Bunchberry Meadows. This forest provides habitat for all sorts of amazing species – from moose to owls to salamanders!We are proud to announce that this forest will be conserved through our Ecological Gifts Program and the Natural Areas Conservation Program.Protecting this land will give Edmontonians the opportunity to share this space with their family for generations to come. .... . : / Kyle Marquardt : / Karol Dabbs : / Karol Dabbs

caption_original: Have you heard of Climate Action ? It’s a project funded by a contribution agreement we have with GreenLearning Canada.Climate Action gives students a voice in building a low-carbon and prosperous Canada and an opportunity to present and engage with the Government of Canada.Today, in a Virtual Town Hall, more than high-school students from across the country discussed climate change with our minister, Catherine McKenna, as well as with Mary McGrath, Executive Director of GreenLearning and host Terry Godwaldt, from the Centre for Global Education. Students presented action plans on three topics – Greening Our Energy Supply, Sustainable Transportation, and Reducing Waste. Students will continue to take action — in their daily lives, at school and in their community while challenging others to act.What's YOUR ?....
